File.Title: Dopaminergic Projection From Nucleus Raphe Dorsalis to Neostriatum in the Rat
File.Authors: LAURENT DESCARRIES, FRANCE BERTHELET, SYLVIA GARCIA,

Abstract.S: The existence of a dopamine (DA) projection from nucleus raphe dorsalis (RD) to neostriatum was demonstrated in the rat by combined tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) immunohistochemistry and radioautography after retrograde axonal transport of ['Hlnoradrenaline (['HINA).

Intrastriatal injections of [3H]NA were carried out in normal rats or after ipsilateral destruction of the nigrostriatal DA system by injection of 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) into the substantia nigra.
Some 1,000 TH-positive nerve cell bodies were counted within the confines of RD as defined by its content in serotonin (5-HT) neurons.
These DA neurons occupied the upper third of the RD and they were part of its small cell population.
In all cases, a small proportion of the TH-immunoreactive nerve cell bodies in RD were retrogradely radiolabeled.
Radiolabeled but immunonegative cells were exceedingly rare.
The double-labeled neurons were generally more numerous after elimination of the nigrostriatial DA innervation than in normal rats.
They mostly lay within the ventral portion of the medial subdivision of RD and always predominated on the [3H]NAinjected side.
Some were also present in nucleus linearis caudalis.

It was concluded that (1) [3H]NA had been taken up and retrogradely transported exclusively by catecholamine neurons; (2) part of the DA cell group in RD projects to the neostriatum; and that (3) most if not all non-5-HT neurons projecting from RD to neostriatum are likely to be dopaminergic.

Introduction.S: The existence of catecholaminein addition to serotonin (5-HT)-containing nerve cell bodies within the nucleus raphe dorsalis (RD) of rat mesencephalon was first reported by Lindvall and Bjorklund ('74) who used fluorescence histochemistry with glyoxylic acid.

In a subsequent study on central neurons showing tyrosine-hydroxylase (TH) immunoreactivity, Hokfelt et al. ('76) confirmed the presence of these catecholamine cells, which represent a caudal extension of the midline dopamine (DA) subgroup A10 in the rostral midbrain (Hokfelt et al., '84).

Since then, the DA identity of the catecholamine neurons in rat RD has been firmly established by means of two different approaches: the combination of microspectrofluorometry with fluorescence histochemistry (Ochi et al., '78) and the demonstration of TH immunostaining in the absence of a positive reaction to dopamine-0-hydroxylase (Nagatsu et al., '79).
The presence of these DA nerve cell bodies probably accounts in large measure for the relatively high endogenous DA content of rat RD (e.g., Versteeg et al., '76; Levitt and Moore, '79).

Recently, additional immunohistochemical data have been published illustrating the distribution of the DA neurons in the rostral pole of the RD, as well as their relative contribution to the greater midbrain DA population to which they belong (German et al., '83; Kohler and Goldstein '84; see also Hokfelt et al., '84).
However, there is as yet little information regarding the projections and thus the functional integration of this DA subsystem (but see Reymann et al., '83; and Pohle et al., '84).
The RD has long been known to contribute a significant input to neostriatum (for recent reviews, see Graybiel and Ragsdale, '83; Carpenter, '84).
In the rat, these afferents Accepted January 3, 1986.
This work was presented in part at the 8th Annual Meeting of the European Neuroscience Association, The Hague, Netherlands, September 1984 (Descarries et al., '84).

have been visualized by the degeneration technique (Conrad et al., '74) and by radioautography following the anterograde axonal transport of neosynthesized radiolabeled proteins (Conrad et al., '74; Halaris et al., '76; Azmitia and Segal, '78).

The topographical organization of the raphestriatal projection has also been investigated by retrograde axonal transport techniques with either horseradish peroxidase (Nauta et al., '74; Miller et al., '75; Pasquier et al., '77; Jacobs et al., '78; Veening et al., '80) or fluorescent dyes (van der Kooy and Hattori, '80; Loughlin and Fallon, '82) as tracers.

Whereas a large fraction of the raphe-striatal afferents appears to originate from 5-HT neurons (Anden et al., '66; Jacobs et al., '74; Lorens and Guldberg, '74; Gyer et al., '76; Halaris et al., '76; Ternaux et al., '77; Kellar et al., '77; Leger et al., '77; Azmitia and Segal, '78; Moore et al., '78; Van der Kar and Lorens, '79; Parent et al., '81; Steinbusch, '81; Steinbusch et al., '81), a smaller, non-serotoninergic contingent has also been suspected (Jacobs et al., '78) and confirmed by means of combined immunohistochemistry and fluorescent-dye retrograde axonal transport (Steinbusch et al., 80; see also Steinbusch et al., '81).

The present study was prompted by the radioautographic demonstration of a selective retrograde labeling of nerve cell bodies in the RD following microinjection of tritiated DA ([3H]DA) or noradrenaline Q3H]NA) into the neostriatum of rats pretreated with a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (Streit et al., '79; Streit, '80; Descarries et al., '81).
Streit ('80) and colleagues ('79) interpreted this finding to be the result of an interspecific uptake and transport of catechoIamine by 5-HT neurons projecting to the neostriatum.

Further experiments, however, indicated that such retrograde labeling was not suppressed after the addition of a tenfold higher concentration of non-radioactive 5-HT to the [3H]catecholamine solution, and always involved a limited number of nerve cell bodies mostly confined to the ventromedial sector of the RD where, precisely, some DA nerve cell bodies had been described (Berthelet, '83).

On the basis of these observations, we hypothesized that this labeling indeed specifically involved DA neurons and meant to test this hypothesis by means of combined radioautographic visualization of retrogradely transported [3H]NA and TH immunocytochemistry.

In order to appreciate the relative importance of an eventual dorsal raphe DA projection to the neostriatum, it was also decided to map and count the whole TH-immunostained nerve cell body population in rat RD.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS

The study was performed in 12 adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (250-400 g), most of which (n = 9) had undergone, 12-15 days earlier, unilateral destruction of the nigrostriatal DA system by local injection of 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) into the zona compacta of the substantia nigra (Ungerstedt, '71).

For this purpose, 8 pg of the drug (6OHDA salt, Labkemi AB, Gijteborg) was freshly dissolved in 4 pl of saline containing 0.1% ascorbic acid and injected in 5 minutes, under pentobarbital anesthesia, according to stereotaxic coordinates A = 2.2, L = 2, and H = -1.7 mm from De Groot's atlas ('67).
Radiolabeling by retrograde axonal transport
All but one of these rats were subjected to intrastriatal injection of [3H]NA.

Tritiated DL or L-noradrenaline was evaporated from stock solutions (NEN, DL - [7-3H(N)]-norepinephrine hydrochloride, and Levo-lring-2,5, -63H]-norepinephrine, spec. act. 5.8-7.5 Ciirnmol and 43.9-48.4 Cii mmol, respectively) and freshly redissolved in isotonic saline containing 0.1% ascorbic acid (final concentrations in the lop3 M range).
The rats were pretreated with a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (pargyline, 75 mgkg, i.p., 1 hour earlier) and anesthetized with pentobarbital (60 mgkg, i.p.1.

The tracer solution (0.5-lpl) was microinstilled (0.1 pl/minUte) into one neostriatum (the lesioned side in 6-OHDAtreated rats) according to stereotaxic coordinates A = 7.6 or 7.4, L = 2.6, and H = 1.0 from Konig and Klippel's atlas ('63).
The amount of radioactivity administered was measured by liquid scintillation and varied between 25 and 40 A survival period of 6-15 hours was allowed prior to fixation (Berthelet, '83).

In two rats (one control, one lesioned), the brain was fixed by aortic arch perfusion with 3.5% cacodylate-buffered glutaraldehyde and directly processed for light microscope radioautography by using standard techniques (Descarries and Beaudet, '83).
In the remaining nine rats (one control, eight lesioned), perfusion was carried out with a mixture of 0.5 or 1% glutaraldehyde and 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.3).

The brainstem was postfixed for 1 hour by immersion in the same fixative containing 5% sucrose but no glutaraldehyde and processed for immunohistochemistry as described below prior to radioautography.
The forebrain (except in two cases) was embedded in paraffin, serially sectioned, and radioautographed as above to verify the exact location and extent of the tracer injection sites.
Combined radioautographic and immunohistochemical labeling
TH immunohistochemistry was performed according to a modified version (Pickel et al., '77) of the peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) method of Sternberger ('79).

Two TH antisera were used one kindly provided by Joh and Pickel and the other by Vigny (methods of production and criteria of specificity described in Joh et al., '73; Pickel et al., '77; Vigny and Henry, '81; Vigny, '82; Berger et al., '82).
The brainstem was serially sectioned on a vibrating microtome from the caudal substantia nigra, rostrally, to the locus coeruleus, caudally.

Free-floating sections (20-30 pm thick) were sequentially incubated with (1) primary (TH antiserum diluted 1:1,500 for 16-24 hours at 4°C; (2) goat antirabbit immunoglobulins (FC specific, Miles) diluted 150 for 30 minutes; and (3) rabbit PAP (Cedarlane) diluted 1:lOO for 30 minutes.
All incubations were carried out in 0.5 M TRIS-saline containing 1% normal goat serum, and 0.2% Triton X was added to the first two solutions of antibodies.
The bound peroxidase was treated for 6-7 minutes with 0.011% 3-3'diaminobenzidine and 0.006% hydrogen peroxide.

The sections were finally mounted onto gelatin-coated slides, slightly contrasted by brief immersion (30-45 seconds) in diluted osmium tetroxide (0.05%), and either coverslipped for immediate examination (one normal control) or dried overnight at 37°C and radioautographed by dipping in Ilford K-5 or Kodak NTB-2 emulsion diluted 1:l with distilled water (nine ['HINA-injected rats).

The immunoradioautographs were exposed for 4-6 weeks in dry, light-tight boxes, developed for 4 minutes in D-19 at 18T, fixed in commercial sodium thiosulfate solution containing a hardener (Kodak), washed in water, rapidly dehydrated in increasing concentrations of alcohol, and coverslipped with Permount after a brief rinse of xylene.
Complementary procedures

For precise anatomical localization of radiolabeled and/or immunostained nerve cell bodies, all light microscopic observations were documented by camera lucida drawings made at an initial magnification of 150x.

One uninterrupted series of immunostained sections from a normal rat together with the map provided by Swanson for TH-immunoreactive elements in the upper brainstem ('82) and the atlas of Konig and Klippel ('63) were used for determining the stereotaxic level of histological sections.

For comparison with the distribution of 5-HT nerve cell bodies at the same levels, some of the material and the topographic map presented in an earlier radioautographic report (Descarries et al., '82) were utilized.
Morphometric measurements of THimmunoreactive cell bodies were performed with the aid of a Bioquant software package (R & M Biometrics).
Cell number estimates were derived from counts of immunoreactive perikarya in series of evenly spaced sections, applying Abercrombie's ('46) formula 1 to correct for double counting errors.

Lastly, a few of the histological sections processed for TH immunohistochemistry were embedded in Epon and reexamined in semithin sections cut perpendicular to their surface so as to determine the depth of immunostaining.

Results.S: RESULTS
Distribution of TH-immunostained nerve cell bodies
Only small differences in the intensity and cellular extent of immunostaining were observed with the two antibodies .
As shown in Figures 1 - 3, a relatively large number of THpositive somata were visualized within the boundaries of the RD .

In unlesioned rats, TH-immunoreactive elements were also seen at more rostral levels of the midbrain and in all anatomical locations where such neurons have been previously described (for review and detailed mapping, see Hokfelt et al., '84).

In 6 - OHDA - lesioned rats , there was a complete disappearance of TH - immunoreactive cells within the nigra and lateral portion of the ventral tegmental area on the side injected with neurotoxin ( Fig . 5 ) .
Within the RD, the distributional pattern of the THimmunoreactive neurons was remarkably consistent from one animal to another (Fig. 3).

This cell group extends rostrocaudally for a little more than 0.5 mm , occupying the rostral third of the nucleus as defined by its content in 5HT neurons ( see bottom row in Fig . 3, and Descarries et al . , ' 82 ) .

It begins rostrally at the level of the oculomotor nucleus as a caudal extension of the subaqueductal portion of A10 ( more precisely , AlOdc as defined by Hokfelt et al . , ' 841, reaches its greatest dimension at stereotaxic level A - 770 pm , and reduces abruptly at stereotaxic level A - 470 pm , where only a few individual immunostained nerve cell bodies remain discernable immediately beneath the aqueduct of Sylvius .

Throughout its rostrocaudal extent , this group of TH - positive cells is contiguous ventrally with the caudalmost portion of the ventral extension of A10 ( nucleus linearis caudalis or AlOc of Hokfelt et al . , ' 84 ) .
As illustrated in Figure 2, numerous TH-imunostained nerve cell bodies in the RD are small and fusiform with, near the midline, their long axis oriented dorsoventrally.
These bipolar cells generally exhibit narrow dendrites that bifurcate at a considerable distance from the perikaryon.
The dendritic branches often appear varicose.
Other immunostained neurons are somewhat larger and definitely multipolar (see also Fig.
On average (n = 1001, the THpositive cells in RD had a sectional area of 117 _+ 4.1 pm2 and a perimeter of 463 k 1 pm.
From these figures, their mean diameter was extrapolated at 13.5 pm.
Direct counts on three series of sections (one control and two lesioned rats) provided an initial figure of 1,435 52 (S.E.M.)
TH-immunostained cell body profiles inside the RD.
The numbers showed remarkable consistency from one animal to the next at every anatomical level examined.
There were no significant differences between the control of 6-OHDA-lesioned rats.
The resin - embedded material demonstrated that the nerve cell body immunostaining extended across the full thickness of the sections .

The data could therefore be corrected by means of Abercrombies's formula 1 ('461, which yielded a final figure of approximately 1,000 TH-immunoreactive nerve cell bodies per RD, assuming that 3 pm of perikaryon had to be contained in a section for it to be detected.
Retrograde radiolabeling and TH immunostaining after intrastriatal injection of [3H]NA
Most [ 3H ] NA injection sites were localized in the medial and ventral portion of the middle third of neostriatum ( Fig . 4 ) .
In normal rat ( cases RAG - 1 and VAL - 7, Fig . 4 ) , the entire neostriatum was still heavily labeled in spite of the 12 - hour survival period .
In 6 - OHDA - lesioned rats , dense labeling was confined to a restricted zone bordering the minute area of necrosis seen at the needle tip ( insert of Fig . 4 ) .

In all cases , retrogradely labeled nerve cell bodies were observed within the boundaries of the RD as well as inside the underlying caudal and ventromedial extension of the VTA ( nucleus linearis caudalis ) ( Figs . 6 - 9 ) .
This labeling took the form of preferential accumulations of silver grains overlying the nucleus and perikaryon of certain neurons and extending into their proximal dendrites (Figs. 6-8).
(Figs. 7 and 8, see p. 484, Color Figure Section).
In normal rats , numerous retrogradely labeled somata were also seen inside the substantia nigra , zona compacta , and in the ventral tegmental area , ipsilateral to the injection side .
A few were also present in the contralateral ventral tegmental area .
After 6 - OHDA nigrostriatal denervation ( Fig . 5 ) , few labeled neurons remained visible in the rostral VTA , and these were only on the injected side .

In the combined radioautographic and immunohistochemical experiments , the vast majority of retrogradely radiolabeled nerve cell bodies in the midbrain raphe as well as ventral tegmentum exhibited TH immunoreactivity ( Figs . 7 - 9 ) .
Strongly labeled but immunonegative neurons were exceedingly rare ( Fig . 9 ) .
Dispersed , weakly labeled immunonegative cells were occasionally detected in the RD following the longest durations of radioautographic exposure .
Only a small proportion of the whole population of TH - immunoreactive cells in the RD ( and nucleus linearis caudalis ) was radiolabeled ( Fig . 9 ) .
The number of doublelabeled cells were generally greater in 6 - OHDA - lesioned than in normal rats .
The double-labeled neurons always predominated on the side of tracer injection.
Rostrally , they tended to cluster in the ventral portion of the medial component of the RD , infiltrating its narrow extension between the two medial longitudinal fasciculi .
Some doubly labeled cells were also present more ventrally , within the nucleus linearis caudalis , but always close to the midline .
No obvious correlation could be made between the location of the intrastriatal injection sites and the number andor particular distribution of the retrogradely labeled TH - positive neurons .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
TH-immunoreactive neurons in the dorsal midbrain tegrnentum

The present study confirms and extends earlier observations regarding the existence of a TH-immunoreactive nerve cell group in the dorsomedial mesencephalon and particularly the RD of adult rat (see references in the beginning of this paper).

Catecholaminergic neurons in rat RD exhibit a microspectrofluorometric spectrum in the DA range (Ochi and Shimizu, '78) and do not stain for dopamine-o-hydroxylase (Nagatsu et al., '79), which suggests that they are dopaminergic rather than noradrenergic.

The presence of catecholamine-containing cells in the RD has also been reported in rabbit (Blessing et al., '781, cat (Wiklund et al., '81; Miachon et al., '841, and monkey (Tanaka et al., '82) by use of fluorescenceor immunohistochemical techniques.

TH-immunoreactive (Gaspar et al., '83; Pearson et al., '83) as well as presumed catecholaminergic, melanin-pigmented neurons (Saper and Petito, '82) have also been described in the dorsal tegmentum of the human midbrain.

The catecholamine cell group in the RD does not seem to belong to the periaqueductal-periventricular DA system described within the central gray of the diencephalon and midbrain by Lindvall and Bjorklund ('74).
Indeed, throughout the midbrain, neurons of the periventricular DA system are sparsely distributed immediately beneath the ependyma1 lining, and mostly circumferentially oriented.

In contrast, the TH-positive grouping in the RD is more compact, shows a preferential longitudinal orientation of many of its elements, and lies in direct continuity with the caudal extensions of the VTA, all features that justify its inclusion into the greater mesencephalic DA family.

In keeping with this general view, the mesencephalic DA system is known to project primarily to striatal, limbic, and/or cortical areas, whereas the periventricular DA system has mainly short diencephalic or descendng long projections (Bjorklund and Lindvall, '84).

The presumed DA population in the RD, estimated here at 1,000 units, corresponds to roughly one-tenth of the total population of mesencephalic DA nerve cell bodies lying outside the substantia nigra proper (i.e., in the area corresponding to the A10 group as defined by Swanson, '82).

The DA raphe contingent is therefore relatively small, especially by comparison with the total number of mesencephalic DA neurons, which amounts to some 15,000-20,000 cells on each side (Hedreen and Chalmers, '72; Guyenet and Crane, '81; Swanson, '82).
Within the RD itself, the DA cells are also a minority since this nucleus consists of approximately 36,000 neurons (Descarries et al., 82).
The 5HT-containing neurons in the RD constitute one-third of this total number (some 12,000 units) and they extend much farther caudally than the DA-containing ones.

It is interesting that within the rostral RD, where the DA and 5-HT populations overlap, both types of nerve cells exhibit a comparable topographic distribution characterized by a medial and two lateral clusters (Fig. 3).
This topographical arrangement might provide a morphological support for some of the 5-HTDA interactions reported to occur in rat RD (Hery and Ternaux, '81; Lee and Geyer, '82).
The TH-positive neurons in the RD appear generally smaller than their 5-HT partners, which average 17.9 pm in diameter (Descarries et al., '82).

In fact, their mean diameter of 13.5 pm is very similar to that previously measured for %on-5-HT neurons" within this nucleus (13.1 pm; Descarries et al., '821, and in the same range as that of the smallest DA cells in the rest of A10 (Kohler and Goldstein, '84)).

These observations contradict previous statements to the effect that there are no clear-cut cytoarchitectonic differences between 5-HT and non-5-HT raphe cells projecting to neostriatum (Steinbusch et al., '80; Steindler et al., '83).
Raphe-striatal DA projection

The presence of retrogradely labeled cells in the RD following injection of L3HINA in the caudate putamen conforms with earlier radioautographic observations after intrastriatal injections of [3H]NA or [3H1DA (Streit et al., '79; Streit, '80; Descarries et al., '81).
The deep location and asymmetrical distribution of many of these cells ruled out the remote possibility of their labeling as a result of intraventricular spread of the tracer.

The fact that almost all of the radiolabeled cells also exhibited TH immunoreactivity demonstrated that I3H]NA had been taken up and transported exclusively by catecholamine-containing neurons and not, as originally surmised (Streit et al., '791, by 5-HTcontainin ones as well.

Injections of comparable concentraf tions of [ HjNA in rat olfactory bulb (Font et al., '82) or cervical spinal cord (Jones et al., '86) have similarly been shown to result in selective retrograde labeling of catecholamine perikarva (locus coeruleus neurons).
Taken together, these data tend to confirm the specificity of [3H]Nx as a retrograde marker for catecholamine-containing cells, even after intratissular injection at relatively high concentrations.
This report provides the first demonstration of a catecholaminergic projection from the RD to the neostriatum in the rat.
The identification of these cells was facilitated by their greater number in 6-OHDA-lesioned than in control rats.
This was presumably due to increased availability of the tracer for uptake and retrograde axonal transport into raphe-striatal neurons after elimination of the massive nigrostriatal DA input.

Moreover, in normal rat striatum, the huge number of nigrostriatal DA terminals capable of accumulating ["HINA probably restricted the diffusion of the tracer to the immediate vicinity of the injection sites.
After 6-OHDA elimination of these terminals, such a DA "uptake barrier" was no longer present (Doucet et al., '85).
In the present experiments, this should have enlarged the size of the neostriatal region from where ["HINA could be taken up and retrogradely transported.

The topography and number of retrogradely labeled RD cells after 6-OHDA lesioning closely resembled that of nonserotoninergic raphe neurons previously identified after retrograde axonal transport of fluorescent dyes from neostritum (Steinbusch et al., '801, suggesting that, in these lesioned rats, the bulk of the non 5-HT raphe-striatal projection was actually detected.
By the same token, it may be assumed that the majority of non-5-HT raphe neurons projecting to neostriatum are dopaminergic in nature.
This is not to say that all DA neurons in the RD project to neostriatum.
Indeed, only a small proportion of TH-immunoreactive neurons in the RD were retrogradely labeled after [3H]NA injection in the neostriatum.

A recent investigation combining retrograde tracing with fluorescent dyes and catecholamine-fluorescence histochemistry has indicated that presumed DA neurons of the RD provide a substantial input to the hippocampus (Reymann et al., '83; Pohle et al., '84).

Retrograde labeling of a few nerve cell bodies in the rat RD following injection of ['HINA in the olfactory bulb has also led Font et al., ('82) to postulate a projection of catecholaminergic neurons from the RD to the olfactory bulb.

Such DA projections could arise from the TH-immunoreactive neurons that were not radiolabeled in the present experiments, although the possibility cannot be excluded that some of the raphe DA neurons projecting to neostriatum collateralize to other anatomical regions as well.

On the other hand, the fact that only a small number of raphe DA cells project to neostriatum, together with the low degree of collateralization of neurons of the A10 DA family to which these cells belong, supports the likelihood of an anatomically restricted projection quite different from the profusely branched and widespread 5-HT RD system.

It remains to be determined whether some of the DA neurons projecting from RD to neostriatum contain other neuroactive substances, such as neurotensin, which has been shown to coexist with DA in nerve cell bodies located in the rostral raphe (Hokfelt et al., '84).

Another colocalized transmitter might be CCK, which has been found in non-5HT nerve cell bodies of the RD (Van der Kooy et al., '81) and is known to coexist with DA in nerve cell bodies of the ventral tegmentum (Hokfelt et al., '80a,b).
CCK-containing raphe cells, however, do not appear to project to the neostriatum (Van der Kooy et al., '81).
Nothing is yet known concerning the intrastriatal distribution of the DA axons originating from the RD.
However.

the fact that raphe DA cells hate already been demon: strated to project to limbic areas suggests that DA raphestriatal fibers might be preferentially distributed within the so-called striosomes, which would correspond to the areas of the neostriatum most intimately linked to the limbic system (Gerfen, '84).
